data.source: European Center for Disease Control (ECDC) COVID-19 cases and deaths; cultural tightness index; World Bank Government Efficiency Index
data.access_details: Data and additional analyses are openly available via OSF at https://osf.io/pc4ef/
data.notes: Infection rates modeled using exponential growth curves transformed to linear growth rates; mortality likelihood defined as deaths-to-confirmed-cases ratio; correlational design with controls (GDP per capita, inequality, median age); some analyses used generalized linear models and logistic regression; study acknowledges causation cannot be inferred.

method.description: Cross-national observational analysis relating cultural tightness and government efficiency to COVID-19 infection growth rates and mortality likelihood, using ECDC data for a short time window and controlling for economic development, inequality, and median age. Models included exponential growth modeling for infection rates, regression analyses with interactions, and generalized linear models/logistic regression for mortality. The paper also discusses evolutionary game theory and agent-based simulations to contextualize dynamics of norms and virus spread.
steps: Collect COVID-19 confirmed cases and deaths by nation from ECDC for March 21–30, 2020.
Compute infection rates (cases per million; growth rates via exponential models transformed to linear) and mortality likelihood (deaths-to-cases ratio).
Assemble predictors: cultural tightness index and World Bank Government Efficiency Index.
Compile controls: GDP per capita, Gini coefficient (inequality), median age (and account for days since first confirmed case in mortality models).
Fit regression models for infection growth rates including main effects and their interaction.
Fit generalized linear/logistic models for mortality likelihood.
Evaluate statistical significance, estimate predicted differences (e.g., cases per million and illustrative US scenario), and compute confidence intervals for mortality rates.
Share data and analyses via OSF.
method.models: Exponential growth modeling (growth rates transformed to linear); linear regression for infection rates with interaction between cultural tightness and government efficiency; generalized linear models/logistic regression for mortality likelihood; discussion of evolutionary game theory and agent-based simulations.
method.outcome_variable: COVID-19 infection rate growth (cases per million; log/linear growth rate) and mortality likelihood (deaths-to-confirmed-cases ratio).
method.independent_variables: Cultural tightness index; Government Efficiency Index; interaction between cultural tightness and government efficiency.
method.control_variables: GDP per capita; Gini coefficient (inequality); median age; days since first confirmed case (for mortality models).

results.summary: Nations with tighter cultures and higher government efficiency experienced significantly slower COVID-19 infection growth and lower mortality likelihood. Each unit increase in cultural tightness and government efficiency was associated with negative coefficients for infection growth. Predicted outcomes indicated substantially fewer cases per million under high tightness and efficiency, and markedly lower mortality percentages compared to low tightness and efficiency nations.

numerical_results.outcome_name: infection_rate_growth (effect of GDP per capita in tightness model)
infection_rate_growth (effect of GDP per capita in government efficiency model)
predicted_cases_reduction_per_million (high vs low tightness & efficiency, 1 month)
